ImageData.LabelName: Red marrow where plasma cells are made

OriginalSource.Creator: Terese Winslow
OriginalSource.Comment: Added the word “cells” in the label above the myeloma cells [Multiple myeloma cells (abnormal plasma cells)]

Changed label “Spongy bone (contains red marrow)” to “Red marrow where plasma cells are made”; changed label "Compact bone" to “Bone”; removed "Yellow marrow" label; changed label "Antibody" to "Antibodies"; changed label “Abnormal plasma cells in multiple myeloma” to “Multiple myeloma (abnormal plasma cells)”; and changed title of image to “Multiple Myeloma”

Removed some of the antibodies from the lower part of the figure and added several more abnormal plasma cells; changed the top label to say “Normal plasma cells” and the bottom label to say “Abnormal plasma cells in multiple myeloma”.
Changed title to “Multiple Myeloma Cells”; Changed “produce” to “make” in the label for normal plasma cells.

Changed the title to “Myeloma Cells in the Bone Marrow”; took out the middle part of the illustration (labelled Compact bone); cut off the part of the long bone about an inch or so below where the cut out part begins; added a few more normal plasma cells and changed the label to say “Normal plasma cells make antibodies”; and added a few more multiple myeloma cells making lots of antibodies and changed the label to say “Multiple myeloma plasma cells make more antibodies than normal cells”.

Diagnoses.Diagnosis: multiple myeloma and other plasma cell neoplasms

ContentDescriptions.ContentDescription: Multiple myeloma; drawing shows normal plasma cells, multiple myeloma cells (abnormal plasma cells), and antibodies. Also shown is red marrow inside bone, where plasma cells are made.

Captions.MediaCaption: Multiple myeloma. Multiple myeloma cells are abnormal plasma cells (a type of white blood cell) that build up in the bone marrow and form tumors in many bones of the body. Normal plasma cells make antibodies to help the body fight infection and disease. As the number of multiple myeloma cells increases, more antibodies are made. This can cause the blood to thicken and keep the bone marrow from making enough healthy blood cells. Multiple myeloma cells also damage and weaken the bone.

ProposedUse.Summary: Plasma Cell Neoplasms (Including Multiple Myeloma) Treatment

ProcessingStatus.ProcessingStatusValue: Approved by expert reviewer with changes
